column4: Hanover to sell specialty unit Chaucer to China Reinsurance for $950 million
column5: (Reuters) - Hanover Insurance Group Inc on Thursday decided to sell its unit that underwrites risks at insurance market Lloyd’s to China Reinsurance Group Corp for $950 million to focus on expanding its domestic business.
column6: Shares of Hanover rose as much as 5.32 percent, with the company saying that sale of the unit, Chaucer, would reduce its catastrophe and tail risk exposure and improve long-term operating return-on-equity potential.
column7: China Reinsurance will fund the deal to buy Chaucer with $865 million in cash and $85 million in dividends from the unit.
column8: The cash part of the deal consists of initial consideration of $820 million payable at closing and $45 million to be held in an escrow account, which may be adjusted if catastrophe losses incurred in 2018 go beyond certain threshold.
column9: “This transaction will enable us to build on the growing momentum in our domestic property and casualty businesses,” said Hanover Chief Executive Officer John Roche in a statement.
column10: The company, whose domestic net premiums have grown 20.6 percent to $4.1 billion in the last five years, plans to expand capabilities in commercial businesses as well as improve penetration in the personal lines and small commercial sectors.
column11: The transaction is expected to close late this year or in the first quarter of next year, subject to regulatory approvals.
column12: Hanover’s financial advisor was Goldman Sachs & Co Llc.
column13: The company’s shares were up 4.3 percent at $120.94 in early morning trading.
